author: Hidden painted rocks in Ohio spread hope and inspiration
title: California's punishing rain creates rare spectacle
text:
California's punishing rain creates rare spectacle CBS News 9 hrs ago Click to expand Replay Video Conservative organizer calls 'alt-right' groups 'left-wing fascists' Dan Schneider, executive director of the American Conservative Union, told attendees at the 2017 Conservative Political Action Conference that members of the 'alt-right' are “anti-Semites, they are racists, they are sexists” on Feb. 23 in Washington. The Washington Post President Trump Described Deportations as a ‘Military Operation’ Time Pope Suggests It's Better To Be Atheist Than Greedy Christian CNN reports that in a thursday speech in rome the pope said it might be better to be an atheist than a Christian who exploits people, lead a double life, get involved in "dirty business," and scandalize the church. Examples of such scandals abound, the Pope said, adding that they erode the church and the guilty Christian from within, by causing others to sin and lose faith. MSNBC 4:38 CBS News poll: 39% approve of Trump's work so far CBS News 4:24 Inside aircraft dropping leaflets over Mosul CNN 1:25 Video showing Calif. off-duty cop firing gun at teens sparks protests CBS News 2:05 Jackie Evancho wants Trump to meet her transgender sister Reuters 1:10 Trump staffers reveal methods to keep president from Tweeting Veuer 0:52 Jeff Sessions swayed Trump on transgender bathroom policy, analyst says TODAY 2:54 Trump's brand of populism shakes up CPAC Reuters 1:13 DNC chair debate in 90 seconds CNN 1:32 Rare sight at California lake as reservoir overflows CBS News 2:21 Singer tweets Trump on transgender policy CNN 2:00 Sec. Kelly: There Will Be No Mass Undocumented Immigrant Roundups NBC News 0:55 UP NEXT First the rain, now the drain. California’s punishing rain this month has flooded neighborhoods and triggered evacuations. It has also pushed Lake Berryessa in Napa County way beyond capacity, pouring water into its bathtub-like drain. It’s the first time that’s happened in 11 years, reports CBS News correspondent Mireya Villarreal.
“Back in October, we were essentially half-full,” said Roland Sanford, general manager of the Solano County Water Agency. “This is the first time that the lake has been so low, and filled-up and spilled in one year.”
© Provided by CBS Interactive Inc. ctm-0223-morning-glory-spillway.jpg What looks calm at the top of the “Morning Glory Spillway” looks like a raging torrent at the bottom. The spillway is located 200 feet from the Monticello Dam. It is shaped like a funnel, 72-feet wide at its lip and narrowing to 28 feet at an outlet down at the Putah Creek. When water in the lake rises to more than 440 feet above sea level, it spills over the lip of a funnel and pours into the creek 700 feet below. When the reservoir reaches capacity, this spillway can take in about 48,000 cubic feet of water per second. That’s the equivalent of draining half of an Olympic sized pool in one second. The drain during California’s drought was so dry that it became an unofficial skateboard park. But water started trickling in on Friday. Now it’s become a bit of a tourist destination. You might say, a hole-y pilgrimage. The spillway could keep flowing for the next couple of months.
